item.title: Bitcoin News for the week of 5/30/16
item.description:
Bitcoin News for the week of 5/30/16

Welcome to our weekly bitcoin news recap, where we cover top headlines and stories in the world of bitcoin each week. This week we saw another run-up in the price of bitcoin, causing more headlines and speculation on why bitcoin is in such demand recently. In addition, investors are flocking to bitcoin, including millennials.

item.title: Ethereum Price Technical Analysis - ETH Consolidating Gains - NEWSBTC
item.description:
Ethereum Price Technical Analysis - ETH Consolidating Gains - NEWSBTC

Ethereum price is consolidating, and may be setting up for the next move. Will it move higher or break down vs the US dollar? Ethereum price is consolidating, and may be setting up for the next move. Will it move higher or break down vs the US dollar?

item.title: The Crypto Show with Yoshi Goto of Bitmain Justus Ranvier of StashCrypto and Jon Vaage
item.description:
The Crypto Show with Yoshi Goto of Bitmain Justus Ranvier of StashCrypto and Jon Vaage

The S9 antminer is here with it's new 16 nm chip and Yoshi of Bitmain is here to tell us about it. Then we talk with Justus Ranvier of StashCrypto and Jon Vaage narrator for Nakamoto Institute about the definition of money and how it relates to Bitcoin.

item.title: Ready to bypass the dollar and buy into bitcoin? - Personal Liberty®
item.description:
Ready to bypass the dollar and buy into bitcoin? - Personal Liberty®

The day is coming when investing in an unregulated electronic currency won't seem so risky or far-fetched. You see, I'm kind of a fan of Bitcoin. The fact that there's a currency that operates outside of the governments of the world is a concept I am on board with.

item.title: Why Bitcoin is a New Asset Class
item.description:
Why Bitcoin is a New Asset Class

Bitcoin is emerging as a unique asset class, according to a recent report by Chris Burniske, blockchain analyst and products lead at Ark Invest, and Adam White, vice president of business development and strategy at Coinbase.

item.title: Hi, not sure if you saw, but I'm that anti-poaching pilot in Central Africa that recently had an issue with M$. Some kind folks donated BTC to us (we were just curious to try), but now we need some advice (being in the bush) on how to use them.. * /r/Bitcoin
item.description:
Hi, not sure if you saw, but I'm that anti-poaching pilot in Central Africa that recently had an issue with M$. Some kind folks donated BTC to us (we were just curious to try), but now we need some advice (being in the bush) on how to use them.. * /r/Bitcoin

Bitcoin is the currency of the Internet: a distributed, worldwide, decentralized digital money. Unlike traditional currencies such as dollars, bitcoins are issued and managed without any central authority whatsoever: there is no government, company, or bank in charge of Bitcoin. As such, it is more resistant to wild inflation and corrupt banks.

item.title: Bitcoin, meet China. May you have many happy days together.
item.description:
Bitcoin, meet China. May you have many happy days together.

Bitcoin, Meet China. May You Have Many Happy Days Together.

item.title: How is bitcoin being used to launder money?
item.description:
How is bitcoin being used to launder money?

Answer: To add more to the story: The scam they were running was from debit cards and credit cards. I did a digging myself as I was fascinated myself but it seems way too secure for anyone to just use it like that.

item.title: How will Bitcoin block chains be updated and maintained once mining becomes unprofitable?
item.description:
How will Bitcoin block chains be updated and maintained once mining becomes unprofitable?

Answer (1 of 2): This is a multiple factor issue, truth be told. Miners receive compensation in two forms: block reward and transaction fees. As the block reward reduces, ultimately fees are supposed to take over to support the miners and their work. But it very well could be that one day there a...

item.title: What do blockchains offer over legacy systems?
item.description:
What do blockchains offer over legacy systems?

"Will the US ever pay off it's debts?" - No. While it is concievably possible for the US to pay off all it's debts, doing so would not make any sense. Revolving debt is how the US is able to fund all of it's programs, invest in infrastructure, etc.
